div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,550] ALEXANDRIA, Friday, JULY 20, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p:
Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
London £ 14. 5/ £ 9.
Maresilles £ 9. 15/ £ 6 15/
Brindisi £ 6. 15/
-
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until 4 June, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. Combined fare to London by sea and train de luxe via Brindisi or via Maresilles £194.11.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

(Electric Light.) SALOON (Amidships) FARE £12. (Latest improvements.)
S.S. RANGOON 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about July 30 for Dover.
S.S. BURMA 5600 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 11 for Devonport.
S.S. PEGU 5800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 18 for Dover
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 12 days thereafter.
Apply WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Conservatory and the Opera House. Lift. Electric Light Throughout. Perfect Sanitary Arrangements. Magnificent Ball, Reception, Reading, and Music Rooms. Bar and Smoking Room.
FINE TERRACE ON THE AVENUE. - SPLENDID GARDEN. - OMNIBUS MEET ALL TRAINS AND STEAMERS. 28-26

TOURIST AND GENERAL PASSENGER AGENTS< BANKERS
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 20 June, 4 and 18 July, 1 and 15 Augsut, 5.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER.”

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature’s Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray’s Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.p: Ramleh-Alexandria
The most charming Sea-side Residence in Egypt.
15 Minutes by Carriage or "Palais tram from Sidi Gaber Station.

First Class Family Hotel with Every Modern Comfort. Unique Situation on the Beach. Lovely Garden. Lawn Tennis. Large Terrace. Electric Light. Sea Baths. Own springs. Perfect sanitary arrangements. Represented at Hamburg by the Norddeutsche Bank in Hamburg.
The bank transacts general banking business of every description and acts as representative of the following foreign banks:

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The N. westerly breeze which has been blowing almost continually for the last month, veered round yesterday to the N.E. The heat and the humidity have increased. This morning opens very sultry. There is a light northerly breeze and a falling harometer. Some wind may be expected towards the close of the day.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The Engish Daily Newspaper, Established 1886
Editor and Manager - - R. SMELLING
ONE PLASTRE TARIFF
Friday, July 20, 1906.
A DANGEROUS SCHEME.

It is sufficient to say of Mr. Haldane's new Army scheme that it more than realizes the worst rebodings to which expression has been given, says the “Globe.” Two battalions of the Gnards and eight battalions of the L'oe are-'o he disbanded. The existing number of 6eld batteries is apparently to be retained, bat their home establishment is to be reduced to a four-gnu basis, except eighteen that are to be put, for some mysterious reason, on a two- gun basis. The net result is a redaction of 3.800 mood in the Riling Artillery, doom pained by an extraordinary arrangement under which certain Militia regiments are to be converted from garrison to Geld artillery, with a view* of supplying the ammnnitim columns to the brigade divisions, and of firm in a Reserve of,gnnnera and drivera. At the time the release of a certain number of ninth of the Regular Garrison Artillery from the dettes of coast defense will allow of their absorption in the Field. The whole of the Militia—Infantry, Artillery, had Beginners -is to be rendered liable to be sent On foreign service, which entails, we • appose, the Goal disappearance of the Militia Ballot, The Volunteers are to be er outraged by the receipt of the abandoned Geld gun*, which Mr. Haldane thinks might be useful in the case of a raid by a Eu rope un Power, and the whole Volunteer force is to be brought into connection with some local authority, -of which the country is to be the unit The details ot this last innovation are still in the dark, and Mr. Haldane Was unable to enlighten the House as to the footings, powers, and constitution of those bodies. Although a total rendition of 20,000 in the Regular AYfny is premised, Mr. Haldane, with the assent outlie) Army Connoil, undertakes to have ready for war an expeditionary force of 160.t)0 \ of wh .m 60,000 msn. will be with the oolongs at home, 70.000 will be Reservists, and the remaining 80,010 mo bilised Militia. The army corps organization is abolished in favor of six big division! of, infantry, containing three brigade! each, after the Indian pattern, four cavalry brigades, and a full complement of artillery, the whole to form a force larger by nearly a third than has hitherto been contemplated for purpose outside the United Kingdom.

0f the disappearance of the term Army Corps we bag no partial complaint to make: it is of German origin; it never Gutted in with oar pa^ system, sod was float to the wind* in time ot war. 'And if a reduction was to be made in the ranks of the Regular Army, it was obvious that the infantry most bus the «offeror* : #vend so, we regret that Mr. Haldane did not are his way to ratio tip cadres of the disappearing battalions rather than resort to the drastic prosoma of disbandment And we think the redaction of the Guards a moat grave error, doe apparently to tome absurd piece of sentiment Bat it' is against interference with the Artillery that we ieel bound to otter the strongest protest of which the language is capable. Mr. Hildaoe gave the film«y pretext that andante pre-sent system only half the existing batteries could be mobilized for want of man and of ammunition columns. Aa Mr. Balfout pointed out in an admirable piece of criticism, a large proportion of these batteries are ot new creation, and time has not yet permitted of the growth of a sufficient Reserve. But this is accumulating year by year, and while nearly 4,000 artillerymen are to be dismissed, Mr. Haldane alters the terms of servi6* for new reaerate, substituting six yean with the toolbars and fix with the Reserve for the present period of three and nine The combination of those two changea most bring about a rapid and automation fall in the number of men annually joining the Reserve The molt its large diminution in the amount of trained artillery experts available for service at home and abroad, in men, moreover, who on neither be improvised or replaced. The makeshift of potting in Militia and Garrison Artillery to assist the Geld batteries is an expedient which we regard with the gravest suspension. Any reference to modem campaign* will show that the ammunition columns require skill and experience discreetly second to what is demanded in the batteries themselves; and the mingling of men trained under diffare’.t conditions and with totally different experiences is bound to introduce a fatal confusion. Mr. Haldane has been guided apparently by the standard of success attained in on# or two picked Militia regiments. WA are afraid he has tens the victim of a generalization based on exceptions. The red notion of the Artillery in South Africa in the face of a native rising, aid the denudation of oar moat important foreign garrisons, IA an act of sheer madness.

Nor does the ’Globe” feel any real oonGdenoe hat Mr.Haldane has secured the 150,000 men for his expeditionary force: his Genres are aim- (vulgarly unconvincing. As we have eo long, been the victim of paper anniee, we may be exoneèd if we hesitate to believe that the present secretary for War has solved the problem that baa be filed all his predecessors. Wa are still met by the old question, when is the British sol tier to come from? The gnat fact remains» that at a moment when the armies outbid- world are striving feverishly to 'ïàoraase their numbers and efficiency, and when the future is black with this prao tical oratory of a straggle for oar national existence, Mr. Haldane proposes to redo the effective strength of the Iritish Army by 20,000 men. The net saving, •o far as we can gather, is to be about a million a year, a windfall which is certain to be appropriated by some crazy fad of modern de moor tie Glance. And was have no guarantee that what is taken eff the shoulders of the not be replaced on those of the ratepayer by the County Associations. These bodies are nebulous for the present, send the utmost we on hype about them is that they will do of harm to the auxiliary forces the probability is that they will be in some shape or other an emanation of tabs County Cannoli. It is ’-perfectly ’notorious that many ot those bodies, all the Welsh tance, that of the West Riding of Yorkshire, and the London County Council itself, are opposed root and branch to what they oil militarism. To a substantial section of the Radical party the British uniform is hateful, the British officer a gilded popinjay. To place the destinies of the metropolitan volunteer’s node the control of the parochial politicians IA ffyiDg Garden» I* a piece of mere lonely ; but if this IA not contemplated. what does Mr. Haldane mean t of all tabs items in h’s disappointing, disheartening, and dangerous programmed, there IA none that will be regarded with moresnspioion than this tampering with the Auxiliary Forces.
